full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Nadia. How are you feeling today?
Client: Hi Dr. Adams. I'm feeling a bit nervous, to be honest. I know we're going to talk about my experience in the hospital, and just thinking about it makes my heart race.
Therapist: That's understandable. We'll take it slow.
Client: Okay, I'll try. It's just... every time I think about it, I feel like I'm right back there in that hospital bed, struggling to breathe.
Therapist: You're safe here. Let's begin when you're ready.

Client: Alright. I remember waking up in the middle of the night, feeling like my chest was on fire. I couldn't catch my breath, and I was terrified. My roommate called an ambulance, and everything after that is a blur of bright lights and beeping machines. The doctors were talking so fast, using words I didn't understand. I felt so alone and scared.
Therapist: You're doing great. Keep going.

Client: The worst part was when they put me on the ventilator. I couldn't speak, couldn't move. I felt trapped in my own body. The tube in my throat was so uncomfortable, and I was panicking, thinking I might never be able to breathe on my own again. Every time a nurse or doctor came in, I tried to communicate with my eyes, silently begging them to help me, to tell me what was happening.
Therapist: That sounds terrifying. You're very brave for sharing this.

Client: It was. I remember one night, the alarms on the machines started going off. Doctors and nurses rushed in, and I could see the panic in their eyes. I thought I was dying. I couldn't even cry or scream. I just lay there, feeling utterly helpless and afraid.
Therapist: You're handling this well. Remember, you're safe now.

Client: I know, but it still feels so real. Even after they took me off the ventilator, I was afraid to fall asleep. I kept thinking I'd stop breathing again. The constant tests, the needles, the uncertainty - it was all too much. I felt like I'd lost control of my own body and my life.
Therapist: It's okay to feel overwhelmed. You're processing it well.

Client: Sometimes, I still wake up in a cold sweat, feeling like I can't breathe. It's hard to shake off that feeling of vulnerability. I used to be so independent, and now I find myself constantly worried about my health. It's like I don't trust my own body anymore.
Therapist: Your feelings are valid. You've come a long way.

Client: Thank you. It helps to talk about it, even though it's difficult. I just want to feel normal again, you know? To not be afraid of getting sick or ending up back in the hospital. But every time I feel even a little under the weather, I start to panic.
Therapist: That's a common reaction. We'll work through it together.

Client: I hope so. It's affecting my studies too. I find it hard to concentrate sometimes, especially when we have classes related to health or biology. It just brings everything back. And I feel guilty for being so affected by this when other people have gone through worse.
Therapist: There's no need for guilt. Your experience matters.

Client: You're right. I'm trying to remind myself of that. It's just... sometimes I feel like I'm overreacting. But then I remember how it felt to be there, thinking each breath might be my last, and it all comes rushing back. I want to move past this, but I don't know how.
Therapist: You're making progress. Let's continue working on this.

Client: Okay. I think I need a break now, though. This session has been intense, but I feel like I've gotten some things off my chest that I've been holding in for a long time. Thank you for listening and guiding me through this.
Therapist: You did exceptionally well today, Nadia. We'll end here.
